instruction: What made Thomas Sankara distinct among African liberation leaders?
response: Sankara stood out because he was a communist who did not reject Marxism as 'European ideas' alien to Africa. He understood that Marxism is 'the generalisation of the lessons of the struggles of the working class on the road to its emancipation the world over, enriched by every battle.' Speaking at the UN in 1984, he linked Burkina Faso's freedom struggle to centuries of revolutionary history - from the American and French revolutions to the October Revolution of 1917 'that transformed the world, brought victory to the proletariat, shook the foundations of capitalism, and made possible the Paris Commune's dreams of justice.' Sankara declared: 'We are the heirs of those revolutions.' Like Che Guevara, Sankara believed in ordinary people's revolutionary capacity. A week before his assassination, he said of Che: 'He taught us we could dare to have confidence in ourselves and our abilities.'

instruction: What concrete achievements did the Burkinabe Revolution accomplish?
response: In just four years (1983-1987), Sankara's revolutionary government achieved remarkable progress. They abolished tribute payments and forced labor to village chiefs, nationalized land to guarantee rural farmers access to their labor's fruits, and increased prices paid to peasants for crops. They launched immunization campaigns that reduced infant mortality from 208 to 145 per 1,000 births, curbed river blindness, and initiated literacy campaigns in indigenous languages where illiteracy had been 92%. Women were encouraged to organize for emancipation - 'The revolution and women's liberation go together. Women hold up the other half of the sky.' They built roads, schools, and housing through public works, and established popular revolutionary courts to try corrupt former officials. All this in one of the world's poorest countries, with 98% rural illiteracy and 40-year life expectancy at the start.

instruction: Who are the enemies of the people according to Thomas Sankara?
response: Sankara identified internal and external enemies. Inside the country: bureaucrats who 'enrich themselves illicitly' through graft and forged documents to become shareholders; the bourgeoisie that enriches itself 'through fraud and bribery, through the corruption of state officials' to import overpriced goods; politicians who 'travel throughout the countryside only at election time' thinking only they can govern - when in fact '7 million Voltaics represent 7 million politicians capable of running this country'; and 'forces of obscurantism' exploiting people 'under spiritual cover, under cover of tradition.' The external enemy is imperialism and neo-colonialism, working through 'unpatriotic people here in our midst' who have 'rejected their homeland.' Sankara declared: 'When imperialism comes here, we will bury it. Ouagadougou will be the bolibana of imperialism - the end of its road.'

instruction: How did Thomas Sankara approach Burkina Faso's relations with France?
response: Sankara took a principled but non-dogmatic approach: 'Each time France makes a decision that does not seem just to us, we will firmly combat it. People with bad intentions call this systematic obstruction, or an anti-French politics. We think that it is the most sincere way to establish a healthy rapport with the people.' But he was willing to support France when justified: when France withdrew from Lebanon, Burkina Faso sent a message of support; when France boycotted Pretoria, Sankara mobilized the non-aligned movement at the UN. His critique of France focused on outdated colonial thinking: 'As long as your representatives think that Burkina Faso is its exclusive territory or that its voice must go through certain African capitals or through men who have been fossilized in institutions by several decades of power.'

instruction: What was Sankara's critique of how France related to African peoples versus African leaders?
response: Sankara identified a fundamental disconnect: 'A group of African leaders can ask France to intervene in Chad, but if you do a poll, you will see that the African popular masses totally reject, as a whole, this intervention. This is why France will always commit an error when they neglect the masses by saying: It was your presidents that asked us to do this.' He warned of historical consequences: 'Tomorrow, the socialists will need to answer for these acts, in perfect agreement with the African leaders but in disagreement with the masses. Let's not repeat what happened in Algeria.' The problem was that 'for a very long time, a French oligarchy came here to reach agreements with a Burkinabe oligarchy on the backs of the people,' leading to anti-French sentiment that was actually rejection of colonial policy, not the French people themselves.

instruction: How did Thomas Sankara respond to Amnesty International's human rights accusations?
response: Sankara argued the accusations reflected 'conditioned information' and double standards: 'In other African countries, people disappear into dungeons without any protest in France. Better yet, France celebrates and congratulates some of these countries.' He cited specific bias: an AFP representative based in another country 'keeps coming to write about what he sees as negative in Burkina Faso, but he never writes about other countries, even the one where he resides.' He acknowledged arrests but noted: 'Even when we are pushed to the limit, and we arrest certain people, we do not fail to release them.' He explained being caught in a trap: 'Either you kill your adversaries, in which case you are condemned for violating human rights, or you do not kill them, in which case your opponents overthrow you.' The opposition, unable to 'speak publicly due to the risk of being properly put back in their place,' instead 'calls international opinion to its aid.'

instruction: What did Sankara say about making errors in revolutionary governance?
response: Sankara displayed remarkable honesty about mistakes: 'Last year, you said that you committed one error per day. Is that still the case?' He replied: 'This year, we are committing more than three per day, because we are doing even more things, and we are making more decisions.' But he framed this mathematically: 'If, out of 3,000 decisions, 2,800 are bad, there are nonetheless 200 that are good. And if, out of 9,000, we only have 500 good decisions, then this progression has not improved the ratio, but, all the same, that makes 300 more good decisions. This is why we are still committing more errors.' This reflected a philosophy of revolutionary action: better to act and make mistakes than to remain passive - the absolute number of good decisions matters more than the ratio when building a new society.

instruction: How did Sankara view the French political right operating in Burkina Faso?
response: Sankara noted that right-wing forces were already active in his country: 'The Right, we are already living with it here: we vote for Le Pen too much in Ouagadougou. Every day the right strives to harm the revolution here, to poison our relations with France, to make it so that foreigners think that Ouagadougou is a cordoned-off city where all it takes is white skin to be rounded up.' He connected local and international reaction: 'We hope that those who will have the power to guide the destiny of France, whether they are on the Right or the Left, will be committed to not provoking an international coalition against France as a result of the racist and colonialist behaviors of their compatriots in Africa.' He warned: 'In Burkina Faso, we will not remain idle with our arms crossed in the face of these repeated provocations... those who attack our people, we will attack them.'

instruction: What trap did Sankara identify regarding revolutionary violence and international opinion?
response: Sankara described being deliberately pushed toward violence: 'They are trying to discredit us by engaging us in an escalation of violence. They manipulate people who provoke us. A provocation that, if repeated, would drive us to commit extremely violent acts, as a last resort.' When asked what he meant, he said: 'I am thinking, for example, of death sentences.' He didn't want to execute opponents: 'No, I don't want us to have to do that. But we are being pushed in that direction so that we can then be denounced.' The trap was explicit: 'Either you kill your adversaries, in which case you are condemned for violating human rights, or you do not kill them, in which case your opponents overthrow you.' This revealed how international human rights discourse could be weaponized against revolutionary governments while ignoring abuses by compliant regimes.

instruction: Why did Thomas Sankara identify as a communist rather than rejecting Marxism as 'European ideas' alien to Africa?
response: Sankara 'stood out among the leaders of the struggles for national liberation in Africa in the last half of the twentieth century because he was a communist. Unlike so many others, he did not reject Marxism as a set of European ideas, alien to the class struggle in Africa.' He understood that 'Marxism is precisely not a set of ideas, but the generalisation of the lessons of the struggles of the working class on the road to its emancipation the world over, enriched by every battle.' Speaking at the UN in 1984, Sankara linked Burkina Faso's freedom struggle 'to the centuries of revolutionary struggle from the birth of capitalism to today – from the American and French revolutions at the end of the eighteenth century to the great October Revolution of 1917 that transformed the world, brought victory to the proletariat, shook the foundations of capitalism, and made possible the Paris Commune's dreams of justice.' Hence his declaration: 'We are the heirs of the world's revolutions.'

instruction: What was Sankara's materialist analysis of the roots of the debt crisis facing African nations?
response: Sankara argued at the OAU conference in Addis Ababa: 'The roots of the debt go back to the beginning of colonialism. Those who lent us the money were those who colonised us. They were the same people who ran our states and our economies. It was the colonisers who put Africa into debt to the financiers – their brothers and cousins. This debt has nothing to do with us. That's why we cannot pay it.' He characterized debt as 'another form of neo-colonialism, one in which the colonialists have transformed themselves into technical assistants. Actually, it would be more accurate to say technical assassins.' The debt 'is a cleverly organised re-conquest of Africa under which our growth and development are regulated by stages and norms totally alien to us. It is a re-conquest that turns each of us into a financial slave.' Sankara called for a 'united front of Addis Ababa against the debt,' warning: 'If Burkina Faso alone were to refuse to pay the debt, I wouldn't be at the next conference.'

instruction: How did Sankara analyze the relationship between class struggle and women's oppression in Burkina Faso?
response: Sankara applied historical materialist analysis to women's oppression: 'Woman's fate is bound up with that of the exploited male. This interdependence arises from the exploitation that both men and women suffer, exploitation that binds them together historically. This should not, however, make us lose sight of the specific reality of women's situation.' He identified the dual oppression: 'It is true that both the woman and the male worker are condemned to silence by their exploitation. But under the current system, the worker's wife is also condemned to silence by her worker-husband. In other words, in addition to the class exploitation common to both of them, women must confront a particular set of relations that exist between them and men, relations of conflict and violence that use physical differences as their pretext.' Sankara traced women's subjugation to the emergence of private property: 'Given this cycle of violence, inequality can be done away with only by establishing a new society, where men and women enjoy equal rights, resulting from an upheaval in the means of production as well as in all social relations.'

instruction: What was Sankara's class analysis of Burkinabè society in the Political Orientation Speech?
response: Sankara identified multiple class forces. The enemies of the revolution included: the bourgeois compradors ('by the nature of their work, agents of foreign imperialism, who hold in their hands the keys to the neo-colonial economy'); the commercial bourgeoisie ('tied to imperialism through numerous bonds... elimination of imperialist domination means the death of the goose that lays the golden egg'); and reactionary feudal forces who 'put the peasant masses in the position of being a reservoir of votes to be delivered to the highest bidder.' The revolutionary forces included: the working class (though lacking 'an organised working class conscious of its historic mission'); the petty bourgeoisie (which could 'slide toward the positions of imperialism' or join the revolution); and most critically the peasantry – 'the social layer that has paid the highest toll for imperialist domination and exploitation.' Despite their 'economic and cultural backwardness,' the peasantry 'has a stake in the revolution and, in terms of numbers, is its principal force.'

instruction: How did Sankara understand the transition from colonialism to neocolonialism in Africa?
response: Sankara analyzed neocolonialism as continuity through substitution: 'In 1960 French colonialism – hounded on all sides, defeated at Dien Bien Phu, and grappling with tremendous difficulties in Algeria – drew the lessons of those defeats and was compelled to grant our country its national sovereignty.' But this was 'merely a transformation of the forms of its domination and exploitation.' The petty-bourgeois intelligentsia 'set about laying the political and economic foundations for the new forms of imperialist domination and exploitation. Fear that the struggle of the popular masses might radicalise and lead to a genuinely revolutionary solution had been the basis for the choice made by imperialism: From that point on, it would maintain its stranglehold over our country and perpetuate the exploitation of our people through the use of Voltaic intermediaries.' Structurally: 'In essence, neo-colonial society and colonial society do not differ in the least... the colonial administration replaced by a neo-colonial administration identical to it in every respect. The colonial army was replaced by a neo-colonial army with the same characteristics, the same functions.'

instruction: What was Sankara's vision for women's liberation through revolutionary transformation?
response: Sankara rejected reformist approaches: 'Was women's position in society understood? Was it understood that the position of women in society means the condition of 52 per cent of the Burkinabè population? Was it understood that this condition was the product of social, political, and economic structures, and of prevailing backward conceptions? And that the transformation of this position therefore could not be accomplished by a single ministry?' He advocated comprehensive transformation: 'Together we must collectively take care that women retain access to work. It is work that emancipates and liberates women by assuring them economic independence and a greater social role.' Beyond economics: 'resolute action must be undertaken aimed at men and at setting up a large-scale network of social facilities such as nurseries, day-care centres, and cafeterias... Men and women will, from now on, share all the tasks in the home.' His conclusion: 'Comrades, no revolution – starting with our own – will triumph as long as women are not free. Our struggle, our revolution will be incomplete as long as we understand liberation to mean essentially that of men.'

instruction: How did Sankara express internationalist solidarity with struggles worldwide?
response: Sankara's internationalism was comprehensive and concrete. At the UN he declared: 'My heart beats naturally on behalf of the sick who anxiously scan the horizons of a science monopolised by arms merchants... I think of all those affected by the destruction of nature and to those 30 million who will die as they do each year, struck down by the formidable weapon of hunger.' On Palestine: 'It fills me with indignation to think of the Palestinians, who an inhuman humanity has decided to replace with another people... Courageous, determined, stoic, and untiring, the Palestinians remind every human conscience of the moral necessity and obligation to respect the rights of a people.' On apartheid: 'The most despicable, the most humiliating thing for the human conscience, is that it has managed to make ordinary the misfortune of millions of human beings.' He linked struggles: 'The popular, democratic, revolutionary struggle of the people of Burkina Faso was one with the struggles to bring down the apartheid regime of South Africa; it was one with the anti-imperialist struggles of the people of Angola, Namibia, Palestine, Western Sahara, and Nicaragua.'

instruction: What was Sankara's analysis of the common enemy facing both Third World peoples and European workers?
response: Sankara articulated a class-based internationalism transcending North-South divisions: 'The popular masses of Europe are not opposed to the popular masses of Africa. Those who want to exploit Africa are the same ones as those who exploit Europe. We have a common enemy.' At the OAU he elaborated: 'There is a crisis today because the masses refuse to allow wealth to be concentrated in the hands of a few individuals. There is a crisis because a few individuals hold colossal sums of money in foreign banks – enough to develop Africa. There is a crisis because in face of these individual fortunes, whose owners we can name, the popular masses refuse to live in ghettos and slums. There is a crisis because people everywhere refuse to stay in Soweto when Johannesburg is directly opposite them.' This analysis grounded his call for debt refusal not as nationalism but as class struggle: 'When we say the debt cannot be paid we are in no way against morality, dignity, or respect for one's word. It's our view that we don't have the same morals as the other side. The rich and the poor don't share the same morals.'

instruction: What did Sankara mean by 'eight million revolutionaries' and his emphasis on revolutionary pedagogy?
response: Sankara articulated a mass-line approach to revolutionary transformation: 'We are eight million Burkinabè; our goal is to create eight million revolutionaries. And no revolutionary has the right to sleep until the last reactionary in Burkina Faso can capably explain the Political Orientation Speech. It's not reactionaries who have to make the effort to understand the speech. It's revolutionaries who have to make the effort to get them to understand.' He insisted on winning the masses rather than coercing them: 'If the masses do not yet understand, it's our fault. We must take the time to explain, and take the time to convince the masses so that we can act with them and in their interests. If the masses have trouble understanding, it's still our fault.' The goal was transforming consciousness through practice: 'We should prefer one step forward together with the people to ten steps forward without the people.' He cited Lenin: 'At the root of any revolution you will find pedagogy... The art of teaching is repetition. We have to repeat and repeat again.'

instruction: How did Sankara critique 'progressive' men who maintained patriarchal practices?
response: Sankara directly confronted revolutionary hypocrisy on gender: 'There is no lack of examples of men, even though progressive, who live cheerfully in adultery, yet would be ready to murder their wives on the merest suspicion of infidelity. Many men in Burkina seek so-called consolation in the arms of prostitutes and mistresses of all kinds.' He named specific behaviors: 'What can be said of those little men, also progressive, who get together and talk lewdly about the women they have taken advantage of. They believe that in this way they'll be able to measure up to other men and even humiliate some of them, by seducing married women. In reality, such men are pitiful and insignificant.' On revolutionary militants: 'There are those more-or-less revolutionary militants – much less revolutionary than more – who do not accept their wives being politically active; or who allow them to be active by day, and by day only; or who beat their wives because they've gone out to a meeting or demonstration in the evening.' He concluded: 'The conduct of these men places them on the side of reaction and counter-revolution. For the revolution cannot triumph without the genuine emancipation of women.'

instruction: What was Sankara's tribute to Che Guevara and its significance, delivered one week before his assassination?
response: One week before his murder, Sankara honored Che on the 20th anniversary of his death: 'It's true, you cannot kill ideas. Ideas do not die. That's why Che Guevara, an embodiment of revolutionary ideas and self-sacrifice, is not dead.' He claimed Che for Africa and Burkina: 'Che Guevara, an Argentine according to his passport, became an adopted Cuban through the blood and sweat he shed for the Cuban people. He became, above all, a citizen of the free world – the free world that we're building together. That's why we say that Che Guevara is also African and Burkinabè.' Sankara defined Che's qualities: 'What is Che? Che, to us, is above all conviction, revolutionary conviction, revolutionary faith in what you're doing, the conviction that victory belongs to us... Che is also a sense of humanity... Che is also, and above all, demanding. The demanding character of one who had the good fortune to be born into a well-to-do family... Yet he was able to say no to those temptations, to turn his back on the easy road in order, on the contrary, to assert himself as a man of the people.'

instruction: How did Sankara address self-reliance and the rejection of aid dependency?
response: Sankara advocated psychological as well as economic decolonization: 'We should get rid of this mentality. Had we not been colonised and therefore not had relations with France to begin with, how could we possibly think we had a right to expect something of France?' He understood the political dimensions of aid: 'Unless you're a masochist or have suicidal tendencies, you don't help your enemy. You don't provide him with arms so he can survive and make his influence felt and convince those around him to follow his example.' Practically, Burkina practiced austerity: 'Our ministers travel economy-class and have an expense allowance of only 15,000 CFA francs per day... Our minister of labour went to Geneva a little while ago for an international conference. With his daily allowance, there's no way he could expect to find a room in Geneva. He had to go to neighbouring France and share a modest hotel room with his colleagues. This is nothing to be ashamed of.' He invited popular verification: 'When we tell countries we're not going to pay the debt, we can assure them that what is saved won't be spent on prestige projects. We don't want any more of those. What is saved will be used for development.'

instruction: What was Sankara's position on armed African states and inter-African conflict?
response: Sankara made a striking argument about African arms purchases: 'When we tell countries we're not going to pay the debt... In particular we will avoid going into debt to buy arms. Because an African country that buys arms can only be doing so to use them against an African country. What African country here can arm itself to defend against the nuclear bomb? No country is capable of that, from the best armed to the least armed. Every time an African country buys a weapon, it's for use against another African country. It's not for use against a European country. It's not for use against an Asian country.' He proposed collective disarmament: 'I am a soldier, and I carry a gun. But Mr. President, I wish we would disarm. Because I carry the only weapon I own. Others have camouflaged the weapons they own.' This connected to his broader analysis: military spending served imperialism and inter-African domination rather than genuine security, draining resources that should flow to development. The solution required African unity – the 'united front of Addis Ababa' – not national military competition.

instruction: What did Sankara say about the concrete meaning of revolution versus revolutionary phrase-mongering?
response: Sankara insisted revolution must be measured by material results: 'Our revolution is not a public-speaking tournament. Our revolution is not a battle of fine phrases. Our revolution is not simply for spouting slogans that are no more than signals used by manipulators trying to use them as catchwords, as code words, as a foil for their own display. Our revolution is, and should continue to be, the collective effort of revolutionaries to transform reality, to improve the concrete situation of the masses of our country.' He defined success concretely: 'Our revolution will be worthwhile only if, in looking back, in looking around, in looking ahead, we can say that the Burkinabè are, thanks to the revolution, a little happier. Happier because they have clean water to drink, because they have abundant, sufficient food, because they're in excellent health, because they have education, because they have decent housing, because they are better dressed, because they have the right to leisure, because they have enjoyed more freedom, more democracy, more dignity. Our revolution will have a reason to exist only if it can respond concretely to these questions.'

instruction: How did Sankara link environmental destruction to imperialism?
response: Before French officials, Sankara made explicit the connection: 'The battle against the encroachment of the desert is a battle to establish a balance between man, nature, and society. As such, it is a political battle above all, and not an act of fate.' He invoked Marx to explain differential responsibility: 'As Karl Marx said, those who live in a palace do not think about the same things, nor in the same way, as those who live in a hut.' Then directly: 'This struggle to defend the trees and forests is above all a struggle against imperialism. Imperialism is the arsonist setting fire to our forests and our savannas.' This integrated ecological crisis into anti-imperialist analysis – environmental destruction was not a technical problem to be solved by aid or technology transfer, but a consequence of the same system that produced underdevelopment and debt bondage. The solution required the same revolutionary transformation: genuine independence, popular power, and development oriented toward the needs of the people rather than the extraction requirements of imperialism.
